This is an improved divider for your common everyday Akro-Mils cabinet. This divider is designed in conjunction with the Bin-Dex organizing system. The Bin-Dex Project is partially Open-Source, so we're putting some of our parts out there.

https://www.facebook.com/getbindex/

This particular divider stays put in the Akro-Mils bin and doesn't fall out. It has a little flat foot on it for some double-sided tape (if needed) and dodged that sprue lump on the bottom of the bin. The Akro-Mils dividers are pretty expensive for what you get, so download this and print it instead.

Printer:

Dimension SST 1200es

Resolution:

.010" Layers

comments.text: Gotta love thingverse! Got the 10164 (64-drawer) unit with all small drawers and they provide a total of 8 junky dividers you have to rip off the back of the drawer chassis. These are way better - nice tight fit and I really like the extra 'foot' on the bottom to keep things divided better. I printed 16 at a time at low quality and they're still better than the ones you get...
comments.author: budude

comments.text:
Cool. Glad you like it. The foot points toward the rear of the bin so that the little curve helps you scoop little parts. The ones that snap off the back of the cabinet are worthless. The dividers that you can buy separate on Amazon are also kinda crappy for the price. My intent is to make a mold of this divider and try to sell them in a bag. Printing is good, but it still takes a long time and is not really cheap depending on the filament.
Post a pic!

print_settings.Notes:: The barrow entrance may be too small for some tastes, but it can be scaled up to 2x larger without a loss of quality. At one and a half scale the entrance is about shoulder height on most 25mm miniatures.

description.text: I designed this barrow entrance after those I have seen in western Europe. The entrance is small, suited better for crouching or crawling than upright entry, and it is built into the earth with a simple stone frame. This will serve as an entrance to any subterranean dungeon or grotto. Whether it's a barrow, a hideout, or a desert tomb, all you need to do is change the color scheme to suit your locale.The standing stone is designed as a marker, I will have characters follow these monoliths to the barrow itself.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a small brim to aid adhesion with these models, and the samples are printed in 0.15 res. I recommend a 0.1 res, but I was in a hurry to have examples printed before I had to leave my house.

The barrow entrance may be too small for some tastes, but it can be scaled up to 2x larger without a loss of quality. At one and a half scale the entrance is about shoulder height on most 25mm miniatures.

As I usually do with any dungeon-terrain print, I sanded the edges where the brim had been attached and put down a black base coat on these pieces. I then proceeded to paint them with Vallejo model colors.

print_settings.Notes:: Designed with Tinkercad, Sliced with Simplify3D

title: Folded Tabor Pipe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Work in progress, especially some of the customizer options, but the pipes are printable, playable, and more or less in tune.

A Tabor pipe is a tin whistle with only 3 holes (thus, playable with one hand). Ordinary straight Tabor pipes are upwards of 270mm long, not really printable on my bed, but if you take the pipe and fold it.... A true Tabor has the 3rd hole on the bottom, a little SCAD work should enable you to add that option.

Ultimately, I want to be able to print two well tuned Tabors (in different keys) in mirror image and attach them to each other so they can be played simultaneously.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High (0.14mm)

Infill:

Default (15% Hex)

Notes:

Nothing special going on in the print process. Overhangs are 45 degrees, except in the holes.

Print takes about 3 hours at 0.14mm layer height and 40mm/s print speed, 15% hex infill, 3 shells and 4 layers top and bottom. A soprano D consumes about 5m of 1.75 filament with the walls set at 0.64mm thick.

The larger parts are having shrinkage problems in ABS - PLA seems to still be working well up to the width of the printer bed. The "Cv1" low variant is much larger than the soprano D, it barely fits on the bed when turned diagonally and is showing a 16 hour print time, consuming 25 meters of PLA... I'm going to try to print that one next, after this hurricane passes. Drying the filament (baking at 180F for 2 hours) and a bit of hairspray on the bed seem to be helping the PLA print stay stuck.

Acetone vapor polishing

Only for ABS, it's not necessary, but can make a nicer finish.

There's a through hole near the end which I put there to facilitate "hanging" this part in a jar over heated acetone - it makes the surface much smoother, but the part will be smelly for a few days.

I heat about 3/4" of water to a boil in a pot, then pour about 1/4" of acetone (nail polish remover works) in the bottom of a glass jar, put the part on a wire hanger in the jar, put the jar in the pot (now heating to just under 100C), put a plate over the jar lid and wait for 10 minutes or so, then remove and let the part sit for a few hours to "firm up the skin" before touching it. Oh, and the water is boiled on the stove, then carried outside (to sit on the grill) to make the hot acetone vapor. I've been dumping the used acetone on a weed growing in the sidewalk, it doesn't seem to mind.

I've heard that "flame polishing" does a similar thing for PLA, but I've never tried it.

References

First: http://www.ggwhistles.com/howto/ is a great guide for practical whistle making... when I get this completely figured out, I plan to mail him one as a thank-you.

OpenSCAD makes parametric design very accessible, and tuning a whistle like this is all about setting up the parameters.

I'm using an app called gStrings on my phone to read the pipes' tune.

Some notes on windway design around p. 29 here http://www.fomrhi.org/uploads/bulletins/Fomrhi-113.pdf

Not sure if I'm ready to engage with this crew yet: http://forums.chiffandfipple.com/viewforum.php?f=1

For a first design, I'm working on a 268mm D pipe, which should also play E, F# and G by opening the bottom 1, 2 and all 3 holes, respectively.

The main trick I have to accomplish is figuring out the "equivalent length" of pipe bends. My first guess was to assign them their "centerline length" which resulted in a very flat tune (pipe too short). So, I moved to assigning each 90 degree corner an equivalent length of the pipe diameter. This gave me a 598Hz D (40 cents sharp), 672Hz E, 752Hz F#, and 798Hz G - all about 40 cents sharp.

For my next iteration, I tried "discounting" the final bend since it opens as a hole. This moved all the finger holes back about 12mm (it was late, I didn't think about it before starting the print and going to bed) - and the tune with the holes "open" is quite similar to the longer pipe with the shorter body. With all holes closed, the D is now about 40-50 cents flat. So, if the overall length hits the middle of trials 1 and 2, D should be getting close, but the holes need to move about 6mm closer to the end. D 572, E 675, F# 760, G 800 before polishing, and just a tiny bit flatter after polishing.

I've printed a couple of Alto G pipes now, one with 6 holes (more a tin whistle than a Tabor) - the low note is still hard to hold, I haven't tried "rigging the fipple" yet - that's next. Also, since the low note is the only one resonating completely through the lower bends, I revised that area to have a larger diameter curve, which does seem to help.

So far, I like the "tone" of ABS and thicker walls better than PLA with thin walls, but there are more variables at play than just the material type. A big variable is hole roughness, if you get a good seal on the finger holes, PLA and ABS sound very similar.

Pipe length affects resonant frequency The printable thing is a musical pipe like a tin whistle, but more compact (and printable). A variety of pipe diameters and lengths are available in the customizer, and the .scad code is available for tinkerers to design their own variants.

Basic resonance in a tuned pipe With the customizer, you can print a variety of whistles to demonstrate. The sopranos print relatively quickly, easily and cheaply (~5m of filament, maybe $0.10 for $20/kg filament), students can have their own whistles to experiment with and keep. Science: Blowing in the mouthpiece starts a resonant wave in the pipe. The instructor can demonstrate on a variety of pipes of different lengths and diameters. Students will experiment on their own. Ear protection is recommended. Closing the finger holes makes the pipe longer and the frequency lower. Compare the length of the pipe to the speed of sound and frequency of resonance. Note how blowing harder can change the resonance from a(n approximate) quarter wavelength to a half wavelength, doubling the frequency in the same length pipe. Playing two identical pipes with slightly different pressures will vary the resonant frequencies enough to demonstrate beat frequencies. Music: Holding all holes shut plays the base note of the pipe (marked near the mouthpiece). Opening the bottom hole plays one tone higher, opening the bottom two holes plays the next tone higher, and opening all three holes plays the next semi-tone higher. The tune to "Lean On Me" is pretty simple to play with this sequence. If you customize a long first pipe, you can fit the next 3 finger holes on the middle pipe. Due to the fold direction, they are opposite of traditional recorder tuning holes, but otherwise work the same. Breath control keeps the note constant, changing air pressure changes the octave the note plays in. Historical: Traditional Tabor pipes move the 3rd hole to the bottom of the pipe - this should be a fairly easy change for an scad tinkerer to make. I think the relocated 3rd hole is the small part of this redesign - having the pipes folded changes the sound produced (albeit subtly through additions of higher harmonics) and also dramatically changes the way the instrument is held, carried, etc. Technology: Students can examine and modify the SCAD code, designing their own variations of the whistle which they can see in 3D on the screen and possibly print.

Nothing exotic
  • Printed pipes in a variety of sizes, hopefully at least one for each student to keep
  • Cell phone with a frequency measurement/tuner application, such as gStrings
  • Calculator app on the cell phone to calculate wavelengths / speed of sound
  • Ear plugs (if students are permitted "free time" with the pipes for experimentation)

remixed_from.author: MakeALot
remixed_from.title: Linear Bearing Y Axis Carriage for ToM

description.text:
I wanted to hack, so I literally hacked the top off my ToM. I assume someone must have done this before, but I can't see one in Thingiverse. There is a plan... ... (hushed tones) I'm going to make the X Carriage run to its full potential
i.e. the belt length between the pulleys - approx. 160mm. and the Y carriage run to the front of the machine approx. 130mm.
This should give me a build platform of 150 X, 120 Y and 120 Z without much trouble.
I'll need to print using PLA so that I don't need all that space heated, but I don't think that will be a problem. I'm afraid all the people who use this in public will need to put HOT warnings on the exposed parts, but it's not as if they were behind glass before. For those of you who don't wish to chop the top off your ToM, you can still use this carriage mod to give you 150 x 80 x 120 prints.

So, take your ToM to a work bench.
Grab your handy Jigsaw and hack off the top (of the ToM). don't cut through your LED strip stuck round the inside top (like I did, duh!) and make sure any cables are clear of the saw blade. Move your trusty spool holder to the back of the machine. I was amazed that I didn't even need to adjust my Z zero position, its just as rigid as before. Although I'll keep an eye on it and reinforce the back corners with aluminium (aluminum) angle if necessary. If you want to follow along here, you'll need to have the Y carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11601. Update:
o I've redesigned the pulley block, moving the limit switch to the front allowing the table to run to the end of the x travel.
o I've updated the X carriage to trigger the endstop
o I've now got 150mm travel on the X Axis, I need to add a wider hot plate
  • added new aluminium plate for HBP 165x140
  • printed item 155 80 60 (x,y,z)
  • printed item 186 * 30 x 40 (x,y,z) placed diagonally
    • Can't really get the Y any larger without moving the head centre (as the rear columns of the case interfere with the bed)
    But overall, I'm very happy with my new extended ToM. :)

comments.text: I was thinking about doing this exact mod the other night but thought I better check and see if anyone else has already done it.  Congrats your mod looks great!
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: Thanks, I was surprised to be the first, I assume others have done similar mods, but have not published them.  The main benefit is the larger bed which works out well. I do have to consider cool drafts with ABS which cause de-lamination of the prints, but apart from that, I've seen no issues and PLA likes the extra cooling.

description.text: THUMB NUT

This is a two-way use object that attracts kids. It can be used as a wall decorator and also as a pencil stand. Generally, we see a pencil stand with shapes of polygons, but I want to create it like a comic thing. So I created a hexagon shaped face, added hands and legs, and 2 rounded holes that look like eyes, and a triangle hole which look like a mouth. These holes are used to place pens or pencils. I designed a V-shaped thing on the top, which is used to hang the object to a wall and it looks like a hat for that hexagon shaped face. I have kept a pencil to get an idea for the viewer about the use of this object. I didn’t make a full hole that surpasses through the backside, because I don’t want the pencils to touch the ground. This object can be used as wall decorator and any tiny things can be placed in that three holes that I mentioned above.

SOFTWARE USED

I used Autocad software to design this. I used options like line, polyline, circle for the shapes. I used commands like Subtract to make holes, Union to combine two objects to view like a single one and Extrude to make a 3D view by extending the lines. Also applied colors through properties command.
NGSS
This is easy to design once you get to know about the commands of the software that I used. I think dimensions are not accurate in this design. Overall, I think it looks good to for the viewers.

Watch youtube videos how a 3D object designed. Think of an object you want to design. Note down the dimensions and requirements to make it. Again go for the youtube tutorials and search for the commands that can full-fill each and every requirement.
Autocad software

Indicates who's turn it is to make the cuppa (coffee or tea).
Bluetack to the fridge or near the jug.
You could print the arrow in a different colour. You could fill the Font and/or picture with a different colour as well. I chose just to texta colour the end of the arrow to keep it simple.

The old Gen6 electronics isn't able to switch off the print bed heating after your print is done. This upgrade enables the printer to switch off the print bed heating by its own: Video: http://youtu.be/Ox5Y_A9-fRc Parts:
  • Printed switch casing
  • snap-in rocker switch for a standard 12.9x19.2mm snap-in cutout size (make sure that the switch can handle the power: At least 5A)
  • 2x M3 nut
  • 2x M3x20mm screw
  • 2x M3 washer

-Print
-Insert nuts into nut traps inside casing (might be a tight fit)
-Attach two wires to your switch
-Pull wires through hole in the back of the casing
-Snap switch in, make sure "0" points down.
-Attach casing to the top of the right z-smooth bar. (see photo)
-Adjust position so that the x-carriage reaches the switch when at max x position.
-Add to your end-g-code (for skeinforge/sfact: .../alterations/end.gmc):
G1 X195 F7000.0 ;Replace 195 with your max x position
-Connect wires between power supply and print bed heater Comments/suggestions are appreciated.

print_settings.Notes:: Temperature change in Gcode corresponds with temp on model.

description.text:
This is a Stepped Overhang top layer Temperature calibrator and a Tower style calibrator.
These models help calibrate PLA filament and lets you see what temperature prints best on your printer. The Gcode has been modified to adjust the temperature automatically to the corresponding temperature on the models.

The Gcode is for the Repetier-Host Default Cura - Slow and Fast settings at 0.2mm

Your printer may not be compatible with this Gcode.

The Temperature range is meant for standard PLA from 175-220C.

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!! Running filament too cold may cause the nozzle to clog and grind the filament or more serious problems. Running the filament too hot will cause it to burn.

Included is a video on how it works and how to edit the Gcode manually to make your own temperature calculator.

Printer:

Frankenprinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

above 0

comments.text: Thank you for the calibration block and the g-code instructions!  I have only had my printer for a couple of months and I am also using Repetier.  I have not seen a lot or, or maybe any, tutorials using this software.  Your video was just the nudge I needed to dig a bit deeper in to it.  Thanks again!  If you have other Repetier videos, maybe post some links :-)
comments.author: XYdwayZ

comments.text: Thanks!  I had issues using the Raspberry Pi with Repeteir server, so I switched to an older desktop.  My prints kept pausing randomly on me, but went away with a faster computer.  I used it for a while though without any other issues.  It was a R-Pi B+ though, the 3 might do a lot better as well as software improvements since then.  But if you're having that problem... it is likely the cause.  I don't have any other links with repetier, but I do have a Youtube channel that teaches how to use Blender.  Just look up inventimark in youtube search.
comments.author: XYdwayZ

comments.text: I am using a Raspberry PI 3.  Also, Repetier has a prebuilt ARM image for Raspberry PI, I think it is new.  I was surprised how easy it was to setup.  The other issue I read folks talking about was stable power so I sprung for the 2.5A adapter to connect to mains power.  Has been stable so far but I will have to stress test it when I get time.
comments.author: inventimark

comments.text:
Hi, I have flowrate issues, but this tower prints perfect for me at 210-215 with my PLA. Could you share your gcode's line width, flowrates, and all those parameters?
Other printings show delamination with a total flowrate of approx 96%, but this doesn't
Thanks!
comments.author: AVZ

comments.text: The flow rate is 100% and the nozzle size and line width is 0.4mm.  If it's printing correctly at those temperatures, then that's the temperature you should use on other models.  It's more than likely you're printing too cold so the layers don't have adhesion.  210-215 seems hot for PLA, but it's probably just your thermistor calibration being off slightly.  You could try calibrating it.  I have a video of it on my Youtube page.
comments.author: AVZ

comments.author: xeruvim

comments.text: I have never used S3D, so I'm not 100% sure.  If you want to make your own however...  If there is an option to export the gcode to a text editor or edit it inside of S3D (which I'm pretty sure it has at least on of those options), then you can export it and edit the gcode manually.  If you watch the video that's included with this, I show you how to edit it.  Just make sure you double check what you type in though!  You just need a text editor to edit gcode.  Find out which layer you want the temperature transition to be at for each temp and change or add it in.  Save the file, load the gcode and it should print and adjust temps as needed.  The original gcode file included is from the current Repetier-Host with Cura on the default min and max settings.

print_settings.Notes:: Avoid using a thicker shell than necessary! I was using a 1.5mm shell later on, and my printer had trouble with the numbers. (I'd recommend a shell width equal to your nozzle size.)

description.text:
I was having problems having the indented A through R showing up on my printer, so I remixed these in Blender. My printer nozzle is .5 mm - the new letters have a tolerance at least as fine as that. (.5 mm or smaller nozzle = okay).

Things remixed:
Letters are now extruded, not indented (allows better painting)
Re-centered the letters/numbers/pips

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer height was .38

Notes:

With a smaller nozzle, you could probably have finer accuracy/smaller letters.

Avoid using a thicker shell than necessary! I was using a 1.5mm shell later on, and my printer had trouble with the numbers. (I'd recommend a shell width equal to your nozzle size.)

Remix Process in Blender

Step 1: Mesh > Clean up > Limited Dissolve in edit mode.
Step 2: Grabbed the face(s) of the indented letter along the Z-axis
Step 3: [Ugly] Expand the letters to be larger. Manual process, as scaling wasn't awesome for my purposes. (Grab a bunch of faces that would be going in one direction, then x/y to slide along the axis.)
Step 4: In wireframe mode, I'd select the faces of each different element (letter, number, pips) and re-center them.

Cura's layer mode was useful as a baseline, post-Blender, to see if the newly formed letter was going to print.
to be filled out

A mushroom made of a rotated parabola and a cylindric stem.
The parabola is actually a projection of a cone cut at a certain angle.
There are two samples of such mushrooms:

  1. Parametric_Parabolic_Mushroom_1 is being generated using these parameters:
    Ht=400; //Total height
    R=120; //Radius of mushroom
    Hs=200; //Height of stem
    Rs=30; //Stem radius
    s=100; //Smoothness

  2. Parametric_Parabolic_Mushroom_2 is being generated using these parameters:
    Ht=500; //Total height
    R=300; //Radius of mushroom
    Hs=300; //Height of stem
    Rs=50; //Stem radius
    s=100; //Smoothness

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner
The logo for the game and character Sly Cooper. I designed this based on the picture in the Fusion 360 designing software. Please do print this file, as well as share it.

Here is a powerbank utilizing two replaceable 18650 batteries. The bank can charge with 5V/2A, and deliver 5V/2A to whatever it is connected to.

Great use as DIY alternative to other powerbanks with unknown cells, and cells can be replaced when worn out. The bank also have the option to be extended, to use as many cells as one wish. However, if done another solution for battery contacts must be developed.

Parts used (besides the printed ones):

Battery contacts salvaged from:

title: DNA Gadget - A double helix in a double helix

description.text:
Update/Warning: 10/6/2016 - I can't get this STL file/design to print.

It looks like my DNA pencil holder can also double as a strange DNA in a DNA helix gadget or fidget thingy.
If you print one these STL files you will have two interlocked DNA models.
Files:

  1. DNA_Helix_Pencil_Holder_Remixed_two_in_one01.stl is very tall 215mm and needs a larger printer to handle.
  2. DNA_Helix_Pencil_Holder_Remixed_two_in_one01_68percent_scaled.stl is scaled down to below 150mm height.

Disclaimer: I have yet to print this and I'm worried about bridging at the top. I'll re-post after I print.

I was able to make this item by duplicating the STL file from the original pencil holder helix design in the slicer software and rotating one copy on top of the other.

I snagged an Alienware Alpha for a great price, but unfortunately it had extremely poor reception where I located the unit, to where I did not have a consistent signal. I removed the built in antennas from the unit and positioned them outside, which helped somewhat, but still not good enough.

However, I had recently purchased a Monoprice Maker Select Mini... a solution presents itself. I ordered two 15cm MHF4 RP-SMA pigtails, and some antennas from an old dual band router, and here we are. Signal is vastly improved - where the stock antennas had no reception, I've got rock solid reception.

Parts

  • Pigtails. Anything similar should work so long as they are MHF4 and at least 15cm/6" long.
  • Antennas. Not the exact ones I used, but same rating. Ensure if you pick your own that they are dual band - I tried some old 2.4ghz high gain antennas and got very poor 5ghz reception.

Installation
Run the pigtails through the bracket's hole, through the bottom casing's holes, and finally through a vent hole on the internal chassis. Stick the bracket on top via some double-stick foam tape.

Monoprice Maker Select Mini

I wanted to print a sign for the bathroom of my company and I've found the "Toilettes" model by Tapion. I liked it, quite humorous, I decied to print that. But hey! That was made of many unconnected objects! Once detached from the printing bed they should be reassembled at the correct distance/position. So I decided to remix the object to resolve that issue.
This object was born. Easy to print, easy to remove from the bed, easy to attach the two models on the toilet doors.
Please post a picture if you use the model!

And if you don't have a 3D printer or you want a better quality object you can order it from Shapeways here: http://shpws.me/MLUY

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You can print swapping the filament color when the base is done, for best result! I think that a black base and a blue/pink of the top part will be a good choice.
The models fits (one at a time) on the MOD-t printing bed in horizontal (you'll have to rotate them by 90*)
For a better result I advice to sand the top of the model with progressively smaller sandpaper (I used 280 - 400 - 600 and 1000). Then I'll apply a bicomponent resin on the top, for better surface. I'll post a picture when done.

How I remixed the original model

In reality, editing STL files is not a great experience. So I decided to redesign from scratch the whole model.
The figures are easily findable on a search engine so I downloaded them and traced the raster image with Inkscape, I've added the lines to connect the unconnected parts, scaled at my desired size and exported as "Pure SVG".
Then I've imported the SVG file from Fusion 360. I've extruded the "main parts" (the black ones of the original file) and then I've extruded the connecting parts (enclosed in the lines I've added), only a fraction of the height.
That was not much work but the result is not bad, isn't it :)

title: Odicforce laser mount for my Quick Fit Carriage

description.text:
A mounting plate for a 2W blue laser module made for my Quick Fit Carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1670305).

The laser module is made of these Parts from Odicforce (~80€):

  • 1.6W+ blue laser diode (capable of more than 2W)
  • AR coated Lens
  • 2.5A laser current source with TTL
  • Laser heatsink (Dimensions are wrong on the website. These values are correct: ~30mm, ~31.5mm, ~60mm)
  • Suggested: Eye protection glasses

You'll need an 40mm 10x 10mm M3 screws and nuts and a Sub-D 26-HD male connector. Soldering is required.

The PWM signal of the cooling fan output is used as input for the TTL signal of the driver. However it must be converted by a circuit because it is 12V instead of 5V and it disconnects ground instead of 12V.

I chose to use a 40mm fan instead of the 30mm fan to efficiently cool the laser and to blow away the smoke. The module is inside a closed channel to allow for a highly efficient cooling.

Notes:

Please select proper printing orientation. Use my manually designed support structures or geometry as orientation. (I wont reorient the parts myself because Solidworks sometimes breaks drawing relations if solids are reoriented.)

This concept has been in my mind for months, without sketching anything I had the concept of what I wanted, I just needed a few hours to design it in tinkercad, it was tricky getting the tolerances correct. But I have to say it turned out really nice, and it should make a nice gift for any WELS enthusiast. If you don't know what the WELS is, it is short for Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod you can check it out at http://www.wels.net

Printing instructions: This is an easy print. The red piece is the only one which needs supports. Don't use platform adhesion for any of them it would effect the ability to insert one piece into another. I wanted to keep this small for anyone with a smaller print bed. It should work fine to scale it up, however this was not designed to be scaled down, and I would imagine that the tolerances would be really tight for most printers.

description.text:
Simple laser cut click housing for the theremin. Open.Theremin.UNO is an Arduino shield to build the legendary music instrument invented by Leon Theremin back in 1920. The theremin is played with two antennas, one to control the pitch and one for volume. The case has openings for the two antennas, the audio jack, the CV jack and the USB and power plug of the Arduino.
For more information on the theremin shield see:
www.gaudi.ch/OpenTheremin
Laser cut the parts from 3 mm material.  To press the little button on the shield I use a 5mm LED where I cut the legs and stick it through the hole in the front plate :-)

The black rocket in the picture is 1:1 whereas the yellow is 1:1.5 and you keep going and can even create Russian style nested egg configurations as the 1:1 will fit in the 1:1.5 and so on which makes them a lot of fun for gift packaging too!

description.text:
Because of space constraints I had trouble mounting a fan to my Reach3d printer. Off a suggestion from a friend I added blower with a small section of 1/4" flexible tubing blowing directly on the part. The blower mount doesn't print as clean as I would like but it is functional. The hole is for a 1/4 NPT barbed fitting. WARNING it will need to be drilled out a bit to fit the barbed fitting. I'm happy with how it turned out but i may add a T and blow from both sides of the hotend. Let me know if you see anything wrong our think of any improvements. Thanks for looking.

Follow this link for the blower on Amazon https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B2ARV22/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Spool Holder for Nova Labs Prusa i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While I like my existing spool holder, I got tired of reaching behind my printer to grab the spool holder (seen in the background), unscrew it, load a spool onto it, screw it back together and replace it. So, I designed this top-mount spool holder for my Nova Labs Prusa i3 (BG8). I believe it should fit all versions of the printer (BG6 - BGIX) done to date. The spool sits up high enough it won't interfere with prints and allows for quick changes of filament since it's only held in by gravity. I haven't used a nearly empty spool with it yet, but it looks like the filament should clear the rail and not rub on it.

All the spools I have fit on this (eSun/Inland, BuMat, ProtoPasta, PolyMakr - different widths and diameters, but all with a 52mm hole) with or without the adapter (50mm), but they roll smoother with it.

This likely won't fit (m)any other Prusa derivative printers since most don't have the top horizontal reinforcing piece and it may be a different size on those that do. If you want to try, it's 33.5mm deep and 40mm tall. Side-to-side total is 162mm.

The axles/adapter are 25mmx150mm and 50mmx115mm respectively. I also included a sparse axle/adapter set which should require a little less filament and time to print. They have a pretty tight tolerance, so you may want to consider splitting them apart if you're concerned at all about them sticking together.

Update: I found that the filament rubbed against the top of the frame when the spools were nearly empty. "V2" includes a mount for the rub rail so that it won't touch the frame (see pic with the blue Left and Right sides).

Update (2017-12-07): Added v3 - completely untested at the moment. I've noticed my V2 spool holder arms have loosened up a little over time causing a sloppy fit and potentially popping off if you bump it while it's loaded with new/heavy spool. This new version will positively hook under the front vertical crosspiece to prevent this.

Update (2017-12-09): v3 is tested and works well for me.

Printer:

Nova Labs Prusa i3 (BG8)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

0.3mm

20%

Notes:

1.2mm top/bottom, 1.2mm walls, 20% honecomb infill. Support is necessary inside of the recess for the shaft, but there's nothing else over 45 degrees

title: MP Select Mini Z Spacer (customizable, no disassembly!)

description.text:
A customizable spacer for the monoprice mini allowing you to print a spacer that clicks onto the z block. This allows you to add any glass thickness to your bed and effectively move your z zero point up to match.

A particularly nice benefit of this style of spacer is that it allows you to insert and remove the spacer without disassembling the machine at all.

Also nice that it prints with no overhangs and no supports at all.

Printer:

mp select mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100% or walls only

Notes:

Normally you can set up the wall widths of your slicer to force the slicer to only generate walls to print this. In Cura especially take a look at the layer view and make sure it did not leave the spacer hollow. If it does make it hollow simply reduce your wall thickness to 0.4mm and increase infill to 100% to force a proper fill.

Installing version WITH levers (no disassembly)

Before anything else, turn on the printer and move the z-axis up a distance greater than the Extra Height you've chosen so that the spacer arm will fit. For example if you're using 1/8" glass you'll want to move the z axis up 4 mm or so.

From the rear of the machine slip the hook side of the spacer through the gap in the tower and click the spacer in place on the side of the z axis block as in the video. Gently tug on the levers to make sure the hooks have clicked in, and use the lever to adjust them if not. A chopstick from the front cover hole can be helpful if you have trouble.

Installing version WITHOUT levers (requires disassembly)

IF you've chosen the spacer without the levers you'll need to disassemble the mini as follows:
Remove the bottom cover of the mini to expose the bottom tower cover screws. Remove the rear white tower cover of the mini by removing the tower screws on the bottom and top. You can also remove the front if you wish, it makes it slightly easier to insert the spacer.

Now just click the spacer in by hand as in the video. Make sure the hooks click over the bottom and top.

description.text:
The Einscan-S is one of the 1st 3D capture devices which work well enough for capturing tooling and machine parts that actually costs less then $4000. However, it's not perfect. The software is a bit too simple and is missing some pretty important things. For example when you select something from a scan that you want to delete, once selected you cannot deselect. There's a lot more. However, one thing that they did which was REALLY bad was they designed it with screw sizes that do not fit for tripod mounts. As such, you have to use their optional tripod which is not all that good.
I got a real tripod, then made the fitting for it in CAD. I made a hole in it for the size screw under the Camera/projector unit. Then I took it a bit further so a tool was not needed. Using the Einscan-S I scanned/captured the top of the stand that it comes with. Then using 3D-Coat I added what I captured to the mount I made in CAD. I've included both versions. Both mounts work in this kind of tripod:
https://www.amazon.com/Adjustable-Tripod-Monopod-Camera-Aluminum/dp/B00ORH1PGA/ref=sr_1_16?s=photo&ie=UTF8&qid=1475637091&sr=1-16&keywords=tripod
There are other tripods like this out there, this is only one example.
For more details about this and more mounts for the Einscan-S that i am considering as well as lots of stuff about using the Einscan-S and other kinds of 3D capture...
Listen to the 3D Printing Today podcast! It's free and has no advertising!
threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com
It's also in iTunes and stitcher radio as "3D Printing Today"

title: MendelMax RepRapDiscount Smart LCD Controller - Top Rail Mount

description.text:
This is a remix of an very nice looking LCD enclosure for the RepRap Wilson. I've simply extended the bottom edge a bit, added two holes just big enough for 10mm M5 bolts so that it can be bolted to the MendelMax's top rail, and closed up the reset button hole slightly, as I had no buttons that would fit the large hole in the original.

Installation is similar to the original:

Print out the LCD case and the mount
Insert 4 M3 nuts into the LCD case mount near the 4 corners
Insert two M5 machine screws, with washers, in the two bottom-most holes
Insert your RepRap Discount Smart LCD Controller into the case
Insert M3 8mm screws into all four corners and gently tighten
Use the t-nuts (preferably along the top rail) and afix the assembly to the MendelMax

Because of how close the LCD is to the M5 screw head, I suggest using a hex-head screw and an 8mm open-ended wrench to tighten down the enclosure to the MendelMax top rail. I strongly recommend the use of one or two washers with the M5 screws, to prevent cracking of the enclosure around the mounting holes.

Modified MendelMax 1.5

description.text:
Need to help young students build number sense and one-to-one correspondence? I have just the game!

Print the ten frame (with number tiles), the die, and the number cards (on paper, not PLA), and grab some counters/erasers. I got the ones in the example from the dollar section at Target, and since it's October, I went with a Halloween theme.

Student partners take turns turning over a number card and placing that many erasers in the ten frame. Next, the other student rolls the die and adds one more, takes one away, or leaves the quantity the same and places the corresponding number tile in the slot on the board. Repeat, and learn while playing this "game"!

This is a simple cube that helps identifying the property of new filament.

The space between markers is 10.00 mm. What I do is to increase temperature by 5 Celsius degrees from 190.00 during the printing and observe layer property of PLA filament. 190, 195, 200, 205, 210, 215. Changing temperature unit to 10 reduces printing time in half.

Once the printing is finished, I pick it up and check strength of the cube. Normal PLA wouldn't break or develop layer separation. I had a bad green PLA filament on the picture that was useless and I printed a cube to convince the filament seller.

title: Lasercut Height Adaptor for Ball Caster (Pololu)

description.text:
---------------------------------ENGLISH ----------------------------------

With this adaptation it is possible to increase the height of the ball caster many times as necessary, depending on the length of your screw.

Also! through this adaptation it is now possible to use 3mm screws which are more common than those who are provided with the ball caster.

This adaptation has support in the grip base as it also serves as a tool to tighten the nuts of the ball caster and thus easily attach to the mechanism.

----------------------------- ESPAÑOL ------------------------------------

Con esta adaptación es posible aumentar la altura de la llanta loca cuantas veces sea necesario dependiendo de la longitud del tornillo a utilizar.

Además! gracias a la adaptación ahora es posible utilizar Tornillos de 3mm los cuales son MÁS comunes que los que son proporcionados con la llanta loca.

Esta adaptación cuenta con un apoyo en la base de agarre ya que también sirve de herramienta para apretar las tuercas de la llanta y así acoplar fácilmente al mecanismo.

A simple corkscrew nutcracker for hazelnuts. It could be scaled up to crack larger nuts - which wasn't my interest since I only need a nut cracker to crack the very small hazelnuts that the kids bring home from playgrounds.

The screw and the box are aligned that way that the weaker z-layer bonding is avoided for cracking the nuts. My first box, which was simply printed from bottom to up, cracked for that reason. This alignment seems to be quite stronger.

The -175 files are a scaled version that should work for walnuts up to a size of 4.5cm.
I haven't tried this though, since my printer is not large enough to print this.

While completing the project of AxiDraw clone http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1796957 I realised that the initial idea of the central block inspired by AxiDraw will not work for me - the linear bearings were not reliably attached to the body which will have negative impact on the performance (bigger play and gaps). AxiDraw was designed to work with relatively small loads and accelerations on the head and a fragile central block with glued linear bearings serves exactly the goal.

So I came to the idea to insert the linear bearing into proper holders and keeping the central block lightweight as in AxiDraw but making it much stiffer. The plan is to use CNC to mill the parts from aluminium but it will work with 3D printed parts as well. The parts of the central block could be eventually made by extrusion of aluminium so the design is technically optimised for mass production. Once I build the prototype I'll publish the GCode used for the CNC (Mach3) and will share some more information.

Also it was used proper aluminium profile (Rexroth-Bosh 30x90 https://www.boschrexroth.com/irj/portal/anonymous/eShop?guest_user=anonymousDE&display=catalog&bridgeSelectedCatalog=MTN&bridgePageId=mechanik_grundelemente ) for holding left and right plates on place - the profile is not expensive and adds extreme rigidity to the design. The original pipe and long shaft with tap for holding the plates doesn't look very reliable for me.

The machine will be controlled by GRBL on Arduino UNO (up to 30KHz pulses) with CoreXY features enabled. Proper stepper drivers with multiple microsteps (50 or 100) will be added to get smoother movement and increased accuracy.

The movement simulation of the model is shown on https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TWRqU6xOh7M

Uploaded SolidWorks design files, IGES. Added the STL files for printing the central block.

27/01/2016 - Uploaded the GCode (.TAP) for milling the central block parts from 16mm aluminium alloy 2017. Stock size is 190x100x16 to fit on Sieg KX1 machine.

The linear bearing holders were milled from 16mm aluminium 2017 on my CNC (Sieg KX1). The initial milling of all 4 parts took ~4 hours but if the GCode is improved it may take only an hour (I have already some ideas how to do this). See some pictures from the already milled parts.

Assembled central block with linear bearings Closer look - you can see the spring retaining ring holding the bearing in place The joint between X and Y axis (screws not inserted)

The belts and the pulleys arrived so I measured the final distances for the central block. It's important to measure the toothed pulleys with placed GT2 belt on top of them in order to get the exact distances between the idler smooth pulleys. So for the parts I have the parameter pulley_space in SolidWork file should be set to 13.65mm, pulley_diam to 12.20mm for idler pulleys diameter.

I'll upload later the updated SW files

Idler pulley (toothed) with GT2 on top measured as 13.65mm Stepper motor pulley with GT2 belt on top measured as 13.65mm Some bad news...

3 Nov 2016...

After assembling the central block I found that the current design is not suitable for my purposes and suffers from fundamental problems:

  • it's not possible to get good colinearity of shafts - even smallest misalignements lead to non smooth movement of bearings

  • the main problem is that we can't align independantly the shafts (for example align in X axis and then in Y axis), i.e. the shafts holders affect each other.

  • the CNC milled parts (when using 3 axis CNC) are very precise until you don't change the position of the detail on the table. This means - to get highest accuracy the parts should be milled in one pass (prima vista). The Version 3 central block parts have CNC milling operations which require turning the parts on table which is bad for hobby CNC production. Like result there are small deviations from dimensions and linear bearing don't tolerate this.

So I decided to suspend this design and start a new version where the problem of the shaft alignments is solved (we can independently align X and Y axis shafts). Anyway - it was a good way to get experience and to find the weak sides of the AxiDraw inspired central block. I'm sure that AxiDraw is suffering from the same problems of the central block and gluing the bearings was a desperate move.

END

The new version V5 of the AxiDraw clone design is ready and the first tests were successful
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pUK8Xv7dVg (4000 mm/min)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxbBbZrk0Z8 (10000 mm/min)

comments.author: luben111

comments.text:
Actually MakerBot 5th gen is using H-bot belt configuration which is a clone of CoreXY but has some major advantages
http://www.galilmc.com/news/whats-new-galil/white-paper-introducing-galils-new-h-bot-firmware
The advantage of H-bot is that it's more stable compared to CoreXY (the support is placed on the frame) but the head is still lightweight as in CoreXY.
If you plan to build 3D printer - try the H-Bot configuration.
